Hello everyone,

I just finished translating this TED talk (English to Japanese), and it would be greatly appreciated if someone could review it. Thanks!

3 weeks ago, my city, Brussels, was hit by brutal ISIS terrorist attacks. In search of nuanced voices about Islam, I discovered mvslim.com, a website run by young Belgian muslims. They had made a list of 10 TED and TEDxTalks by inspiring muslims. They were all available for subtitling, except for one. I transcribed it together with my friend, TED OTP Arabic Language coordinator Anwar Dafa-Alla. I would like to encourage you to discover this gem and to let Noor Tagouri shine by translating her talk.

Thank you to all the translators who are working on or who have already posted translations to my TED talk "How to get back to work after a career break." I am indebted to all of you and appreciate your hard work very much.  Sincerely, Carol Fishman Cohen, CEO, iRelaunch

A month ago I finished the Chinese, Simplified translation of Ivan Coyote: Why we need gender-neutral bathrooms, it had been reviewed by another contributor Huazhe Xie, and was published about two weeks ago. But the TED webpage seems to have a glitch or a bug, making the mistake of saying that I am the reviewer, while Xie is the translator. Hi team! Check out this awesome message TED speaker Siyanda Mohutsiwa requested to be passed along to our wonderful OTP tribe. :) Let's help Siyanda get her talk translated into many languages, in particular French, Portuguese, Arabic, and Swahili, which are spoken by many people in Africa.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
My talk was supposed to be about a hashtag, but somehow it became a talk about hope! When I gave this speech in Amsterdam, at the end of it, an older African man came to find me, and he had tears in his eyes—a man the age of my father! He told me he had once been a refugee, moving from Congo to the Netherlands. He told me that my talk had reignited in him a love of Africa and had softened the anger he had towards men like Kabila and Mobutu who had all but destroyed life for ordinary people in his region. To me this was most moving. 

When the talk went up on TED after I gave it in Vancouver for a larger audience, I got emails from all over Africa expressing the same feeling: hope. But here’s the thing—not that many people will see it. The vast majority of Africans have no access to this stuff. But I believe in my heart, whoever I can reach with my message—the message of some kid in Botswana who just wants to share the message of a hopeful tomorrow to a continent filled with those who see no reason to believe, I might reach someone. I might reach future leaders who just might see this speech and carry in their hearts this compassion—a compassion that we desperately need and which we unknowingly have in all our cultures (all over the world!) and maybe, these leaders of tomorrow, will make a change that we so desperately need.

But the other thing is: not everyone speaks English in Africa. And although I have real plans to learn French and Swahili and Portuguese and one day Arabic, I have full faith in you all to help me spread my message with the elegance with which you have done others, as soon as you can. I would deeply appreciate that, and I know one day, so will the Francophones and Luophones and babui ba Swahili and the Arabians who make up this great big continent I call home.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

At 8:53, the speaker talked about a passage between South America and Antarctica, which is named the Great Passage in the transcription. Hey team!
I need your help! I recently transcribed the TEDxMaastricht talk "Doing the impossible, cutting through fear”. It's reviewed and approved in English and is available for translation. http://youtu.be/v7tqyim1qhw

But I NEED YOUR HELP! I'm requesting you to please translate my talk in as many languages as possible starting with Chinese (Simplified /Traditional), Japanese, Korean, Thai, Arabic, Urdu, Hindi, Bengali, Punjabi, Gujarati, Nepali, Tamil, Telugu, Indonesian, Javanese, German, Dutch, Danish, Norwegian, Swedish, Icelandic, Finnish, Spanish, Italian, French, Brazilian Portuguese, Russian, Ukrainian, Czech, Hungarian, Bulgarian, Hebrew, and any other languages you work in!

The past few weeks I've had a crash course in translating and transcribing and I'm blown away! Thank YOU for all the work you do for the TED community in making the work of speakers available to the world! Your gift of translation helps spread ideas and touch lives in a huge way to so many people who would otherwise be shut out from the free education that TED /TEDx talks provide. The world relies on community and the TED communityand my fellow speakers are lucky to have all of you and YOUR gift of communication! I hope you’ll have fun translating my talk – its aim is to be a universal message that people CAN cut through fear and do the impossible in THEIR lives! 

Thank you for helping spread ideas worth spreading and thank you for helping me take my simple message to the rest of the world!! I'm looking forward to seeing your translations! Please let me know if you need any clarifications on anything! 

All the best,

Dan Meyer

Hi team!

TED speaker and co-founder of Airbnb, Joe Gebbia, needs our support. He is hoping we can help translate his talk in as many languages as possible, starting with Spanish, Chinese (Simplified and Traditional), Japanese, Korean, German, French, Italian, and Brazilian Portuguese. Here is a note from Joe which he asked to be passed on to you:

Dear Translators,

Thank you for the work you do for the TED community, in making the work of the speakers accessible to the world. I've gotten a crash course in who you are and what you've accomplished, and I'm blown away. The gift you're giving is touching so many people who would otherwise be shut out from the free education TED provides. As someone who also relies on community in our organization, TED is lucky to have you. And so are my fellow speakers. I hope you have fun with my talk – its aim is to be a universal message about trust. So thank you for bringing that message to the universe.

Joe

I am happy to share with you an Open Educational Resource (OER) about Learning subtitling using TED OTP. This is an activity to introduce advanced language learners to subtitling, using our volunteer community.
Scholars, me among them, from three European Universities have developed and tested this OER. This Didactic Unit has been designed by Anna Comas-Quin and myself. We have this OER licensed under Creative Commons by NC. That means, you can share — copy and redistribute the material in any medium or form— ; and also adapt — remix, transform, and build upon the material—, as long as you credit us and license your new creations under identical terms.
The resource is published at LORO an online platform which contains resources for language teaching available to download and reuse http://loro.open.ac.uk/4802/

A couple more questions for this talk are bothering my translation team and we'd appreciate help from native & near-native speakers of English:

1. What does "the average sensual man" mean in the excerpt below? 
"...and the author of the Beveridge Report, had little faith in what they called the average sensual or emotional man. Instead, they trusted this idea of the impersonal system and the bureaucrat who would be detached
and work in this system."

The phrase "had little faith in the average sensual (or emotional) man" seems to be an expression taken from a book. 

2. "So some years ago, wanting to understand this problem, I started to work with a group of about 60 older people in South London, where I live."

By "60 older people", does she mean "60 elderly people" or "people over 60 years old"? 

Thanks a million!

Some recommendations for the ROMANIAN TRANSLATORS: 
Am observat ca mute traduceri, suna foarte fortat si pretentios, e necesar ca fiecare traducator sa stie ca ei traduc si ADAPTEAZA, la limba romana, traducerea cuvant cu cuvant, nu inseamna neaparat ca e o traducere CORECTA, Traducerea trebuie sa fie adaptata la limbajul in limba romana, trebuie sa curga in mod natural. Nu ma refer in mod special la idioms. Va dau un exemplu de un idiom: " Ball is in your court" care cuvant cu cuvant tradus inseamna: mingea e in curtea ta. Bineintels ca fiecare stie ce inseamna in idiom si nimeni nu va traduce fraza aceasta folosind cuvandul "mingea" sau "curte". Autorul nu a descris un joc cu mingea in curte. De aceea e necesar sa nu traduceti cuvant cu cuvant, ci sa adaptati traducerea si traducereea corecta este: "E randul tau acum sa hotarasti ce vrei sa faci" sau: depinde de tine. Insa, sunt cazuri cand aveti de traduc o fraza care nu e un idiom, insa fraza care va da de furca, trebuie tratata ca un idiom si adaptata la limba romana. Cateva sfaturi: evitati infinitivul. Nu suna natural, si ia si mult spatiu. Il puteti inlocui cu conjuctiv. De asemena, nu lasati prepozitii la capat de rand. E foarte important sa cititi cu voce tare ce ati traus si daca suna fortat sau pretentios, aveti libertatea sa inlocuiti si sa adaptati textul, atata timp cat pastrati idea autorului, si nu deviati de la subiect. Daca aveti cea mai mica banuiala ca autotul foloseste un idiom sau nu sunteti siguri, folositi google si aflati daca fraza respectiva e in lista de idioms sau cereti ajutor, aici. Sper ca am fost de folos. va urez mult succes si astept feedback. :-)

I have a question about syncing. I take great care in syncing the subtitle exactly at the start of the speech, in my view it enhances the overall experience of watching the video.
Now, I've noticed that with TEDx talks, playing on Youtube, the sync is exactly as in the Amara editor. With TEDTalks though, playing in the proprietary TED environment, the sync seems to get shifted forward by what looks to be about 0.3 seconds, it's clearly noticeable. So, instead of the sharp cut audio-visual as it was created in the Amara editor, you get this weird feeling of precognition on the TED platform after publishing. Anything I can do about this?

Hello, 

I've finished translating the TEDx Talk: "A ilusão da aparência" | Sara Ortins | TEDxFCTUNL from Portuguese to English. In this TEDx Talk, Sara, who has a precarious health condition, warns us for the fact that a normal, healthy appearance, can deceive our look and hide serious health problems that aren't revealed to strangers, by feelings of shame from who have them. It's a lesson of life and a wake up call for a more sensitive, compassionate and emphatic attitude from us to the Other apparently equal. 

So, because I think it's a TedTalk worth sharing, I'm contacting you to know if someone is willing to review my translation.

Hi translators,

The name of the Project “Best of TEDxTalks” in Amara has recently been changed into “English translation needed (TEDx)”.

The new title in a better and clearer way describes the goal of this project: it contains talks recommended by you, the TEDx organizers, or the local audiences; talks that our editorial and review teams would love to watch with English subtitles and consider them for further distribution.

Start working on these talks if you have time and free tasks: they need your help in every step (transcript, translation, review).

If you know of other great talks that we should know about, in any language, let us know!

Hi, guys! He's back! Michael Green's first TED Talk introducing the Social Progress Index reached nearly 1 million viewers across 27 languages. Now his new video from the recent TED event in London, just released today, poses the question "Can we achieve the Global Goals?" The answer is a resounding YES, based on new research--but not with business as usual. 

He introduces the People's Report Card, a new way for people everywhere to hold their governments accountable for delivering on their promises made at the United Nations.

We need to get this video in front of audiences in EVERY UN member state, and we need help of this awesome group of volunteer translators to make that happen. 

Spanish, German, and Arabic especially important this week.

Who's in?

I am Enid Kim from TEDxKFAS team.
We recently held a TEDx conference here in Seoul, and some of our talks (in English) are still waiting to be reviewed.
We would much appreciate it if you could help us out by reviewing them! 
They are rather fun talks about China's future and nanotechnology. :)

Thank you in advance for your help!

China’s Domestic Transformation and Global Security Impact by 2025 | Feng Zhu | TEDxKFAS

Hi! I am posting this on behalf of Gautam John (a TED India 
 Fellow who talked about an open source publishing model Pratham Books was working on at the 2013 retreat). Gautam is not on Facebook and has requested to post this here : 

We've just launched Pratham Books' StoryWeaver 3 weeks ago: https://storyweaver.org.in. StoryWeaver is an open source platform of multilingual children’s stories. Log on from a desktop computer, laptop, tablet or mobile phone and you can then read from a collection of 800+ stories in 27 languages. You can create a new story from a bank of 2000 images. You can translate any of the stories into newer languages and share them
with others. You can print and use the stories in the way that you want. And also connect with a community of content creators and readers. And this is just the beginning. We will continue to grow the repository through more participation and more collaboration with like-minded partners.

I was wondering whether the TED translation community might both find value in the platform and add value by translating stories in to their languages. 

Thank you!

*****************
We are currently looking for collaborators for the Weave-a-Story campaign : http://bit.ly/8o9WaSc. 
If you are unable to find your language on the site, please email us at storyweaver@prathambooks.org to add it and we will try to add it as soon as possible.

A user experiences Amara editor "Error saving subtitles" overly frequently.  We have found the saved text to download always contains control character x08. It is also reproducible. When I copy and paste x08 code in Amara editor. It will always show "Error saving subtitles" dialog.

(Edited: added the following) The user hasn't done anything intentionally to enter x08 in Amara editor, but somehow the character gets entered and will cause "Error saving subtitles" error. Hi everyone! I am TED's Russian translator. I mostly do the Ted-ed videos (you can see my translations of The Use of Metaphor, Why Shakespeare Wrote in Iambic Pentameter, What is an Earworm? and some others). I really like Ted-Eds. The issue might not be new, but we have been discussing it in our Russian FB-group and we have decided to bring it on international board. We want the names of translators be visible. We think it's quite natural to sign what has been done by you. Why not allow us to sign our works by writing TRANSLATED (into Russian) BY after the text of the scripts as the "last (additional) capture" or in the description after the author's name and the animation by info? We could put Author, Animation, Translation. Maybe also Edited by? If it's not a new issue, so give me some feedback on that since I am relatively new to TED.com (I started this year). Thank you!

I'm making some promotional posters for our TEDxMileHigh Transcribathon and I would like to translate a few quotes from previous TEDxMH into as many languages as possible to put on the poster.  Listed below are five different quotes.  Please comment or message me with translations in your language.  I don't want to rely on Google Translate in case it is inaccurate :D  Thank you so much!!

1. It's not about doing the occasional big things, it's about doing the consistent small things.
2. People will support you when you start working with purpose.
3. If you can achieve all of our goals, dreams and ambitions in your lifetime, then believe me when I say that you're not thinking big enough.
4. Leave here and use your voice. Implore others to use theirs.
5. We are all explorers.

l after you share a talk. Whenever you log into TED.com and share a talk, ted we'll start counting how many views it receives from people clicking on your links.
________________________________________
How does it work?
When you log in to your TED.com account and share a talk, we'll create a special sharing link just for you. You can share the talk using the social media buttons, or just by cutting and pasting the link. Each time someone follows your special link - and watches the video - one view will be credited to you.
If you don't have a TED.com account, you can sign up here.

An international community of volunteer translators and transcribers who are passionate about "Ideas Worth Spreading"

New members are approved regularly. However, if you need urgent help and have not yet been approved as a member of this group, please send us an email to translate@ted.com.

http://www.ted.com/participate/translate
http://translations.ted.org/wiki
tinyurl.com/OTPLearningSeries
https://twitter.com/tedotp

For support, please contact:
tedsupport@universalsubtitles.org (Amara issues)
or
translate@ted.com (everything else)

***Group etiquette***
1. Posts should be related to translation, languages and the Open Translation Project.

2. Be respectful toward others at all times. Racism, discrimination and inflammatory posts are prohibited.

3. Do not post advertising material/spam.

4. Posting about bugs should be avoided. Please send your bug reports to tedsupport@amara.org or translate@ted.com

5. Refrain from posting transcript corrections. Please send your corrections to translate@ted.com

Today Amara released several changes which should improve your subtitling experience:

1. In the editor, each subtitle now has an option menu, which can be accessed by hovering over the wrench icon. (see image)

Menu options include: seeking the video to the point where the subtitle plays, inserting a subtitle above / below the active subtitle, deleting the subtitle, and adding a time-coded note associated with the subtitle.

2. New keyboard shortcuts (see image)

3. SHIFT + SPACE no longer triggers the video to play or pause

4. Subtitles with invalid timestamps won’t be allowed (i.e. two subtitles which start and end at the same time)

5. When comparing two revisions, red text indicates the text has changed. A red box outlining the time codes indicates a timing change. (see image)
